questions.text: Identify the clinical condition in the given karyotyping:
questions.solution:
Numerical chromosomal abnormalities:

  • Down's syndrome (mongolism) or trisomy 21 (Option D):
    • In this disorder there are 3 copies of chromosome 21 (trisomy 21), i.e., there is an extra chromosome 21.
    • The karyotype of patient is 47XY +21 or 47XX +21
  • Patau's syndrome (Option C):
    • In this disorder there are 3 copies of chromosome 13 (trisomy 13).
    • The karyotype of patient is 47XY +13 or 47XX +13.
  • Edward's syndrome (Option B):
    • In this disorder there are 3 copies of chromosome 18 (trisomy 18).
    • The karyotype of patient is 47XY +18 or 47XX +18.
  • Klinefelter's syndrome:
    • It is a trisomic condition found only in males.
    • It is caused by nondisjunction of XX chromosome during gametogenesis.
    • As a result the chromosomal complement in somatic cells is XXY.
    • The karyotype of patient is 47XXY.
  • Turner's syndrome:
    • It is a monosomic condition found only in females.
    • It occurs due to loss of one X chromosome following nondisjunction of X chromosome during meiosis.
    • As a result the chromosomal complement in somatic cells is 45XO.
    • The karyotype of an individual is 45X.
  • Super female or triple X syndrome:
    • It occurs due to fertilization of XX-containing oocyte by an X-containing sperm (gynosperm).
    • The karyotype shows 47 chromosomes.
    • The individual is phenotypically a female with two Barr bodies, hence referred to as 'super female.
    • The chromosome complement in somatic cell is 47XXX.
  • Cri-du-Chat syndrome (cat's cry syndrome) (Option A):
    • This condition is caused by a deletion in the short arm of chromosome 5 so that part of chromosome 5 is missing.

Reference: TB of Clinical Embryology by Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition, Page Number - 349, 351

questions.text: According to fascicular architecture, the muscle shown in the figure is of which of the following type?
questions.solution:
• The muscle shown in the figure is tibialis anterior.
  • When the fasciculi are oblique to the line of pull, the muscle may be triangular or pennate (feather-like) in the construction.
  • This arrangement makes the muscle more powerful, although the range of movement is reduced.
  • Oblique arrangements are of the following types:
  • Triangular:
    • Temporalis
    • Adductor longus and brevis
  • Unipennate (Option A):
    • Flexor pollicis longus
    • Extensor digitorum longus
    • Peroneus tertius
    • Palmar interossei
  • Bipennate (Option B):
    • Rectus femoris
    • Dorsal interossei
    • Peroneus longus
    • Flexor hallucis longus
  • Multipennate (Option C):
    • Subscapularis
    • Deltoid (acromial fibres)
  • Circumpennate (Option D):
    • Tibialis anterior

Reference: B. D chaurasia's Handbook of General Anatomy, 6th Edition, Page Number - 134, 135

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is being tested in the given figure?
questions.solution:
Testing of Some Intrinsic Muscles:

  • Pen/pencil test for abductor pollicis brevis:
    • Lay the hand flat on a table with the palm directed upwards.
    • The patient is unable to touch with his thumb a pen/pencil held in front of the palm.
  • Test for opponens pollicis:
    • Request the patient to touch the proximal phalanx of 2nd to 5th digits with the tip of thumb.
  • The dorsal interossei (Option B):
    • They are tested by asking the subject to spread out the fingers against resistance. As index finger is abducted one feels 1st dorsal interosseous
  • The palmar interossei (Option A):
    • By placing a piece of paper between the fingers and seeing how firmly it can be held.
  • Adductor pollicis (Option C):
    • By placing a piece of paper between thumb and index finger and seeing how firmly it can be held.
  • Froment's sign, or the book test:
    • It tests the adductor pollicis muscle.
    • When the patient is asked to grasp a book firmly between the thumbs and other fingers of both the hands, the terminal phalanx of the thumb on the paralysed side becomes flexed at the interphalangeal joint (by the flexor pollicis longus which is supplied by the median nerve).
  • The lumbricals and interossei are tested by asking the subject to flex the fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints against resistance.
  • The abductor pollicis(Option D):
    • They are tested by asking person to abduct the thumb against resistance.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page Number - 136, 137

questions.text: Identify the bone marked with * in the given figure:
questions.solution:
• Talus (Option D) and calcaneum are better seen in lateral view.
  • Navicular (Option A) and cuboid (Option B) are seen clearly in almost all the views.
  • Cuneiform (Option C) bones are seen separately in dorsoplantar views; they overlap each other in a lateral view.
  • Metatarsals and phalanges are seen separately in dorsoplantar views, but overlap each other in lateral views.
  • Sesamoid and accessory bones should be distinguished from fractures.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-2, 9th Edition, Page Number - 201, 202

questions.text: All of the following structure is forming the boundaries of the marked foramen in the figure, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Foramen Epiploicum (Foramen of Winslow):

  • The foramen epiploicum is a vertical slit through which lesser sac of peritoneum (omental bursa) communicates with the greater sac of peritoneum.
  • It is situated behind the right free margin of lesser omentum at the level of T12 vertebra.
  • Boundaries:
    • Anterior:
      • Right free border of the lesser omentum
      • Bile duct (Option A)
      • Vertical part of the hepatic artery (Option D)
      • Portal vein (Option B).
    • Posterior:
      • Inferior vena cava
      • Right suprarenal gland.
    • Superior:
      • Caudate process of the caudate lobe of the liver
    • Inferior:
      • First part of the duodenum
      • Horizontal part of the hepatic artery (Option D)
    • Hepatic vein (Option C): it does not form boundary of the epiploic foramen.

KEY NOTE: Pringle manoeuver - clamping of hepatoduodenal ligament (free border of lesser omentum) to differentiate if the bleeding is due to hepatic artery or portal vein

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-1, 4th Edition, Page Number - 82

questions.text: The given figure is showing the upper surface of 1st rib. Which of the following structure is related to marked area?
questions.solution:
1st Rib:

  • Superior (upper) surface
    • It is crossed obliquely by two shallow grooves (anterior and posterior) separated by a slight ridge.
    • The ridge is continuous with the scalene tubercle.
    • The anterior groove lodges subclavian vein (Option C).
    • The posterior groove lodges the subclavian artery (Option A) and lower trunk of the brachial plexus (Option B).
    • The area behind posterior groove up to the costal tubercle provides attachment to the scalenus medius muscle (Option D).
    • The area in front anterior groove and near the anterior end provides attachment to subclavius muscle (anteriorly) and costoclavicular ligament (posteriorly).
  • Lower surface
    • It is related to the costal pleura.
  • Anteriorly, the neck is related from medial to lateral side to:
    • Mnemonic-Chain pulling a VAN
    • Sympathetic chain
    • Posterior intercostal vein
    • Superior intercostal artery
    • Ventral ramus of first thoracic nerve

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-2, 9th Edition, Page Number - 227, 228

questions.text: The marked structure opens in to which of the following part of nasal cavity?
questions.solution:
Marked structure is frontal sinus which opens in to the middle meatus.

The openings in the lateral wall of the nose as follow:

KEY NOTE - following DACRYOCYSTORHINOSTOMY(DCR) , the opening of nasolacrimal duct (NLD) is done in middle meatus

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-1, 4th Edition, Page Number - 250

questions.text: Which of the following marking in the figure is representing the abducent nerve?
questions.solution:
Marked structures in the figure are as follows:

  • A - Abducent nerve
  • B - Facial nerve
  • C - Trigeminal nerve
  • D - Oculomotor nerve

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-1, 4th Edition, Page Number - 79, 85

questions.text: What is the epithelium of the structure given in the figure below?
questions.solution:
Given figure is of oesophagus.

  • Mucous membrane:
    • Epithelial lining is non-keratinised stratified squamous (Option A).
    • Lamina propria consists of loose connective tissue with papillae.
  • Muscularis mucosa:
    • It is distinct in lower part and formed by longitudinal muscle fibres.
  • Submucosa:
    • It contains mucus secreting oesophageal glands.
  • Muscularis externa:
    • It is composed of striated muscle in upper third, mixed type in middle third and smooth muscles in lower third.
    • Its outer layer comprises longitudinal coat and inner layer comprises circular coat of muscle fibres.
  • Option B - stratified columnar epithelium - male urethra
  • Option C- transitional epithelium - kidney , urinary bladder , ureter , prostatic urethra
  • Option D- pseudostratified columnar epithelium - upper respiratory tract , membranous urethra etc.

Reference: I. B. Singh's Textbook of Human Histology, 10th Edition, Page Number - 177, 178

questions.text: Marked structure in the given figure is derived from which of the following embryological part?
questions.solution:
Given figure is of thoraco-abdominal diaphragm:

  • The diaphragm is a dome-shaped musculotendinous partition that separates thoracic cavity from the abdominal cavity.
  • The pericardial and pleural cavities lie above the diaphragm while the peritoneal cavity lies below the diaphragm.
  • Marked structure is central tendon of diaphragm
  • The diaphragm is a composite structure that develops from four embryonic components.

Source of development of diaphragm:

Reference: Textbook Clinical Embryology by Vishram Singh, 3rd Edition, Page Number - 227, 228

questions.text: Which of the following nerve is suppling to the muscle shown in the figure below?
questions.solution:
Muscle shownin the figure is levator scapulae

  • The levator scapula is a slender muscle.
  • Origin:
    • Transverse processes of atlas and axis vertebrae.
    • Posterior tubercles of the transverse processes of the 3rd and 4th cervical vertebrae.
  • Insertion:
    • Upper part of medial border of scapula (from superior angle to root of spine).
  • Action:
    • Elevate the scapula and steady the scapula during movement of the arm.
  • Nerve supply:
    • Direct branch from anterior primary rami of C3 and C4.
    • C5 fibres from dorsal scapular nerve.

Muscles supplied by nerve with root value

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-1, 4thEdition, Page Number - 65, 69

questions.text: Which of the following structures are passing through marked foramen in the figure below?
questions.solution:
Mandibular foramen:

  • It is located a little above the centre of ramus and leads into mandibular canal which runs downwards and forwards into the body to open on its external surface as mental foramen.
  • It provides passage to: Inferior alveolar nerves and vessels (Option B)
    • Inferior alveolar nerve: a branch of the posterior division of the mandibular nerve
    • Inferior alveolar artery: a branch from the 1st part of the maxillary artery
    • Inferior alveolar vein

Mental Foramen

  • Present on the external aspect of body of mandible below the interval between premolar teeth and transmits: Mental nerves and vessels (Option A)
    • Mental nerve: a branch of inferior alveolar nerve
    • Mental artery: a branch of inferior alveolar artery
    • Mental vein: a tributary of inferior alveolar vein

Structures related to mandible:

  • Lingual nerve and vessels (Option D) run on the inner surface of the body close to the medial side of the root of the 3rd molar tooth.
  • Mylohyoid nerve and vessels run in the mylohyoid groove.
  • Masseteric nerve and vessels (Option C) run through the mandibular notch.
  • Auriculotemporal runs to the medial side of the neck.
  • Marginal mandibular nerve across the lower border of the mandible.

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-3, 4thEdition, Page Number - 27, 28

questions.text: Figure is showing the structures passing under extensor retinaculum of lower limb. Identify the marked structure.
questions.solution:
• Superior Extensor Retinaculum
    • It is a broad band of the deep fascia, just above the ankle joint.
    • Medially, it is attached to the lower part of the anterior border of the tibia.
    • Laterally, it is attached to the lower part of the anterior border of the fibula.
  • Inferior Extensor Retinaculum
    • It is a Y-shaped band of the deep fascia, situated in front of the ankle joint and the proximal part of the dorsum of the foot.
    • The stem of Y lies laterally, and the upper and lower bands lie medially.
    • The stem of Y is attached to the anterior nonarticular part of the superior surface of calcaneum in front of the sulcus calcanei, medial to the extensor digitorum brevis.
    • The upper band of Y passes upward and medially to be attached to the anterior border of medial malleolus.
    • The lower band of Y passes downward and medially over the foot to fuse with the deep fascia of the sole.
  • Structure passes medial to laterally(The Himalayas Are Not Dry Plateaus)
    • Tendon of Tibialis anterior (Option B)
    • Tendon of extensor Hallucis longus (Option D)
    • Anterior tibial vessels
    • Deep peroneal Nerve
    • Tendon of extensor Digitorum longus (Option C)
    • Tendon of Peroneus tertius (Option A)

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-2, 4thEdition, Page Number - 379, 380

questions.text: Which of the following ligament is preventing the downward displacement of the organ shown in the figure below?
questions.solution:
The organ shown in the figure in the question is the spleen.

Ligaments of the spleen:

  • The spleen is completely enclosed in the peritoneum except at its hilum, from where peritoneal folds extend to the stomach and to the left kidney, called gastrosplenic and lienorenal ligaments, respectively.
  • Gastrosplenic ligament (Option C):
    • It extends from the hilum of the spleen to the upper one-third of the greater curvature of the stomach.
    • It contains short gastric vessels.
  • Lienorenal ligament (Option B):
    • It extends from the hilum of the spleen to the anterior surface of the left kidney.
    • It contains tail of the pancreas, splenic vessels and pancreaticosplenic lymph nodes.
  • Phrenicocolic ligament (Option A):
    • It is a triangular fold of the peritoneum which extends from the left colic flexure to the diaphragm opposite to the 10th rib.
    • It passes below the lateral end of the spleen, which it supports; hence, it is also termed sustentaculum lienis.
    • It prevents the downwards displacement of the spleen.
  • Lesser omemtum (Option D):
    • It does not give attachment to spleen.

Reference: Textbook of Anatomy by Vishram Singh, Volume-2, 4thEdition, Page Number - 96

questions.text: Figure is showing the cross section of thorax at the level of T3 vertebra. Identify the marked structure.
questions.solution:
At the level of the first costochondral junction structures marked in figure below

Keys are as follow:

  1. Manubrium of the sternum
  2. Brachiocephalic trunk (Option D)
  3. Right brachiocephalic vein
  4. Trachea
  5. Scapula
  6. Left brachiocephalic vein (Option C)
  7. Left common carotid artery (Option A)
  8. Left subclavian artery (Option B)
  9. Oesophagus

Reference: Textbook of Grey's Anatomy, 42th Edition, Page Number - 1065
